instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-0521: What is 820-0521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message:
This one had a little damage with <RESISTOR>R7679</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R7678</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R7677</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R7671</RESISTOR>. replaced them all, can't see liquid damage anywhere else but it did have a short with <CAPACITOR>C7676</CAPACITOR>, replaced that too. 
Now the trackpad clicks so I guess it's kinda turning on but no post

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message:
Do you get voltage on the big coils?

Inspect audio board/flex for liquid signs.
Remove the small audio board and check both sides.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message: Actually i have audio board disconnected entirely just in case, is it required to post?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message:
i get 0V on all the coils around the CPU
I get 12.3V on L7030
3.3 on l7690
2.6 on l7670

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message:
"2.6 on l7670"
Is that steady voltage?
Not good; check the correct ohm value for all <RESISTOR>R7671</RESISTOR>/7/8/9.
Be sure to have good traces.

Also check diode mode to ground at L7670.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message:
Yep it's 2.6 on l7670 steady 

Diode is 0.37

interesting, i mistakenly replaced <RESISTOR>R7671</RESISTOR> with a 10k resistor instead of 10 ohm. i replaced it back to the correct one (they are all correct now) and now it doesnt show any sign of life, no track pad click either. I can see that p5g3s is only 90 ohms from ground. A little low isnt it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message: diode mode on <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> is 0.05. that's almost short right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message:
Check diode mode after 10-15s, once power removed.
You didn't have low value before.
Something happened when you've changed the resistors.
Be sure all have good continuity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message:
sorry i'm wrong, yes it's 0.35 diode now. My mistake
but l7670 is now 1.6V. what the hell. this thing is trolling me

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message:
Check all components and traces in the <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power supply.
Pay atention to <CAPACITOR>C7699</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7664</RESISTOR>/5/6.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message:
all checks out ok but it came back with the 0.05 diode on 5v rail. SO i injected 5V. I can see U810 heating up clearly. Took it off, normal diode readings. Then i replaced with another "GAY" chip from a different model donor. (i'm literally trying to find the donor i got it off and can't find it). The one that was originally on there is "GAY SJN" the one i replaced it with is GAY SJ5
It's the only chip i found that looks like is the right one. And sure enough it has normal diode reading with this but it still doesnt boot

also i think i solved the trackpad click mystery, there was a little tweezer nick in the flex, i sorted that and the click is back

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message:
Do you mean <CHIP>U8110</CHIP>?
Check if <RESISTOR>R8144</RESISTOR>/7 are both good now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message:
yes that's what i meant
they both measure good i think. <RESISTOR>R8147</RESISTOR> measures 0 ohms and <RESISTOR>R8144</RESISTOR> measures 4.5 ohms. I assume it's good? I see schematic lists as 2.2 ohms each

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message: Wait, this is now turning on for no reason hahaha. But there's no backlight. just image

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message: i also get keyboard backlight so i assume it isnt SMC lid right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message: do you have any ideas what could be causing BL issues?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was dead with liquid damage, no post now
threads.message:
Did you try known good LCD assembly?
Do you get <SIGNAL>5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL>?

Check <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> voltages; pins 5, 18, 11, 17.
Also check <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>-53 and their traces to J8500 and <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>.
Compare voltage and diode mode for SCL/SDA lines with good board; do the same for <DIODE>D8410</DIODE>.
